text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two horizontal registers framed by a single border. The top register depicts a battle assault scene, the bottom register shows the aftermath, with text blocks above and below the image and marginal glosses at left and right. Wide borders contain architectural and foliate ornament.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with precise, uniform letters and frequent use of ligatures and abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf provides a luminous background reserved for divine context. Ultramarine and vermillion garments alternate to distinguish figures. Layered pigment application with white lead highlights on robes and horse trappings. Red and blue color pairing guides visual flow. Overall pigments are well-preserved with minimal darkening.

features: Diagonal thrusts of lances create dynamic flow
Overlapping horses and foot-soldiers suggest depth
Symmetrical framing unifies upper and lower registers

decorative_elements: Diapered gold backgrounds with white quatrefoils
Marginal gloss script as decorative border

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen work in brown ink with bold outlines and finer internal hatch strokes
drawing_technique.shading_method: Parallel hatching in drapery folds and horses’ bodies, white lead highlights for volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling with no vanishing point, depth indicated by overlapping and size hierarchy

reading_order: Top register first, lower register second

scene_relationships.subject: Assault on the city of Jericho by Joshua’s forces
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads directly to the captivity and judgment of the defeated kings below
visual_connections: Blue tunic of central knight echoed in lower figures
Castellated city wall motif continues at the base of the lower scene

scene_relationships.subject: Joshua binding and presenting the captured kings
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Concludes narrative sequence; no subsequent scene
visual_connections: Red tunics mirror those worn by assailants above
Diagonal gestures of captors echo lance angles in upper scene

visual_continuity: Alternating red and blue garment hierarchy
Consistent hierarchical scaling of principal figures
White lead highlights on figures and horses unify scenes

content_theme.scene_description: Primary Scene Analysis: In the upper register approximately fifteen mounted knights and foot soldiers clash at the walls of a crenellated city gate. Central figures are in full chainmail and conical helms wielding lances and swords; one white horse rears as its rider thrusts a spear. Fallen soldiers lie at the base of the wall. In the lower register, seven standing figures in tunics and chausses bind five prostrate crowned prisoners. A commanding figure, likely Joshua, wearing a blue tunic and short mantle gestures toward the bound kings. The composition uses overlapping to suggest crowding; registers are separated by an architectural arcade. Costume details include pointed poulaines, mail chausses, surcoats in alternating red and blue, and fine belt buckles. Secondary Elements: Both registers are framed by a crenellated architectural border. The gold‐leaf background is diapered with white quatrefoils, symbolizing divine presence. The initial 'P' in the upper margin is foliate and set in burnished gold. Direct Textual Relationships: Latin captions above and below describe the conquest and captivity, with rubricated initials marking key verses. Marginal glosses in brown ink echo the image by referencing Joshua’s triumph. The placement of text above and below the central image drives a top-to-bottom reading flow, reinforcing narrative sequence.

secular: Knights in chainmail and conical helmets mounted on white and brown horses with decorative caparisons
Foot soldiers in short tunics and mail chausses with spears and round shields

objects: Round and heater shields painted red and blue
architectural: Crenellated city walls and twin towers

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, finely scraped and pumiced for a smooth surface, raised gesso supports gold leaf
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal flaking; slight abrasion at margins; gold leaf remains bright; evidence of early repair to lower left corner
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso decoration under gold leaf
Visible underdrawing in brown ink under UV
Regular ruling in leadpoint for text and image boundaries

functional_analysis.primary_function: Biblical narrative illustration within a psalter or Bible manuscript
secondary_functions: Memory aid for preaching on Joshua
Didactic demonstration of divine promise fulfillment
Status display of patron’s learned commission
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Clerical or monastic readers engaged in scriptural study

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This two-register illumination illustrating Joshua’s conquest of Jericho demonstrates hallmark features of a mid-thirteenth-century Paris workshop. The use of burnished gold leaf, diapered backgrounds, and alternation of ultramarine and vermillion pigments reflects the high technical achievements and material wealth of the period. The Gothic textura quadrata script and the precise layout of text and image indicate production in a professional scriptorium, likely for an ecclesiastical patron seeking both devotional and didactic functions. Compositionally, the sequential narrative employs dynamic diagonals and overlapping figures to animate the military assault and the subjugation of kings, linking Old Testament typology to contemporary notions of divine justice. Architectural frames echo contemporary Gothic structures, reinforcing the manuscript’s cultural context within the French royal court’s patronage network. Iconographically, the illuminated page underscores the theological message of covenant fulfillment, with Joshua presented as a divinely guided leader, prefiguring Christ’s victorious kingship. Compared to the Psalter of Blanche of Castile, this illumination shares a similar color palette and decorative vocabulary but exhibits a more pronounced narrative drive in its two-tiered format. The collaborative execution suggests multiple hands at work, with one specializing in figures and another in decorative borders. Overall, this folio merges traditional iconography with innovative compositional approaches, exemplifying the transitional aesthetic between Early Gothic linearity and the emerging naturalism of later thirteenth-century illumination.
